verses.text: The word of the LORD came to me, saying:
verses.comment: This introduction formula highlights prophetic authority; compare to the calling of prophets like Jeremiah (Jer. 1:4).

verses.text: Son of man, prophesy against the shepherds of Israel; prophesy and say to them, even to the shepherds, ‘Thus says the Lord GOD: Woe to the shepherds of Israel who feed themselves! Should not the shepherds feed the sheep?’
verses.comment: The 'shepherds' are Israel's leaders, priests, and kings. Their failure prefigures Christ, the Good Shepherd, as referenced in John 10:11.

verses.text: You eat the fat, you clothe yourselves with the wool, you slaughter the fat ones, but you do not feed the sheep.
verses.comment: Spiritual leaders abusing their flock is condemned. Note the imagery of 'eating the fat,' emphasizing greed over self-sacrifice.

verses.text: The weak you have not strengthened, the sick you have not healed, the injured you have not bound up, the strayed you have not brought back, the lost you have not sought, but with force and harshness you have ruled them.
verses.comment: True shepherds must care for the vulnerable. Jesus fulfills this as the healer and seeker of the lost (Luke 15:4-7).

verses.text: So they were scattered, because there was no shepherd, and they became food for all the wild beasts.
verses.comment: Scattering points to exile and spiritual confusion. Christ restores unity to the flock.

verses.text: My sheep wandered through all the mountains and on every high hill. My flock was scattered over all the face of the earth, with no one to search or seek for them.
verses.comment: This underscores Israel's dispersion, but also God's plan to gather His people again. Jesus’s parable of the lost sheep recalls this imagery.

verses.text: Therefore, you shepherds, hear the word of the LORD:
verses.comment: A pronouncement against unfaithful leaders, emphasizing accountability before God.

verses.text: As I live, declares the Lord GOD, surely because my sheep have become prey, and my sheep have become food for all the wild beasts, since there was no shepherd, and my shepherds have not searched for my sheep, but the shepherds have fed themselves and have not fed my sheep—
verses.comment: God holds leaders responsible for neglect; the language is emphatic ('As I live'), signifying a solemn oath.

verses.text: therefore, you shepherds, hear the word of the LORD:
verses.comment: Repeating the call stresses the gravity of God's coming judgment.

verses.text: Thus says the Lord GOD: Behold, I am against the shepherds, and I will require my sheep at their hand. I will stop them from feeding the sheep, and the shepherds shall no longer feed themselves. I will rescue my sheep from their mouths, that they may not be food for them.
verses.comment: God declares Himself the true Shepherd who will hold leaders to account. Implies divine authority supersedes corrupt human leadership, prefiguring Christ’s role as head of His people.

verses.text: For thus says the Lord GOD: Behold, I myself will search for my sheep and seek them out.
verses.comment: God personally involves Himself in the salvation and gathering of His people. This anticipates Christ's self-identification as the Good Shepherd—He, too, seeks the lost himself.

verses.text: As a shepherd seeks out his flock when he is among his scattered sheep, so I will seek out my sheep; and I will rescue them from all the places where they were scattered on a day of clouds and thick darkness.
verses.comment: The rescue is direct and personal, a messianic role fulfilled in the Incarnation where God comes among His people.

verses.text: And I will bring them out from the peoples and gather them from the countries and will bring them into their own land. And I will feed them on the mountains of Israel, by the streams, and in all the inhabited places of the land.
verses.comment: Promise of return and restoration, not just physical but spiritual. 'Feeding' suggests spiritual nourishment through God-ordained means.

verses.text: I will feed them with good pasture, and on the mountain heights of Israel shall be their grazing land. There they shall lie down in good grazing land, and they shall feed in rich pasture on the mountains of Israel.
verses.comment: Imagery points to Psalm 23; spiritual food denotes God's ongoing care, with undertones that God's provision involves both word and sacrament.

verses.text: I myself will be the shepherd of my sheep, and I will make them lie down, declares the Lord GOD.
verses.comment: Here, God claims the role of the only true Shepherd, anticipating Jesus’ claim in John 10. This statement is a strong assertion of divine care and leadership.

verses.text: I will seek the lost, bring back the strayed, bind up the injured, and strengthen the weak; but the fat and the strong I will destroy. I will feed them with justice.
verses.comment: God’s justice includes both mercy for the humble and judgment for the proud, paralleling Christ’s ministry to sinners and rebuke of hypocrites.

verses.text: As for you, my flock, thus says the Lord GOD: Behold, I judge between sheep and sheep, between rams and male goats.
verses.comment: Judgment within the flock echoes the final judgment scene in Matthew 25; God separates the faithful from the unfaithful within His people.

verses.text: Is it not enough for you to feed on the good pasture, that you must tread down with your feet the rest of your pasture? And to drink of the clear water, that you must muddy the rest with your feet?
verses.comment: God rebukes the strong sheep for ruining spiritual goods for others; leadership must not deprive others of grace.

verses.text: And must my sheep eat what you have trodden with your feet, and drink what you have muddied with your feet?
verses.comment: This further emphasizes the responsibility leaders have to ensure the spiritual purity and good order of the flock.

verses.text: Therefore thus says the Lord GOD to them: Behold, I myself will judge between the fat sheep and the lean sheep.
verses.comment: God is present in the ongoing guidance and judgment of His people, indicating a need for visible authority.

verses.text: Because you push with side and shoulder, and thrust at all the weak with your horns, until you have scattered them abroad,
verses.comment: 'Horns' are symbols of power; abusing authority is condemned—God will protect the weak.

verses.text: I will rescue my flock; they shall no longer be a prey. And I will judge between sheep and sheep.
verses.comment: God’s direct action delivers the faithful and purifies His people—suggesting a continuing visible church in history.

verses.text: And I will set up over them one shepherd, my servant David, and he shall feed them; he shall feed them and be their shepherd.
verses.comment: 'My servant David' points to the Messiah, fulfilled in Jesus (Matt. 1:1), the true and eternal Shepherd.

verses.text: And I, the LORD, will be their God, and my servant David shall be prince among them. I, the LORD, have spoken.
verses.comment: Combines God's kingship with the office of a visible, appointed leader, prefiguring Christ's dual role as God and Messiah.

verses.text: I will make with them a covenant of peace and banish wild beasts from the land, so that they may dwell securely in the wilderness and sleep in the woods.
verses.comment: A new covenant is promised, bringing peace and spiritual security. This is further fulfilled in Christ’s work.

verses.text: And I will make them and the places all around my hill a blessing. I will send down the showers in their season; there shall be showers of blessing.
verses.comment: Blessing on God’s 'hill' references the spiritual center of worship, further implying a visible, continuous worship community.

verses.text: And the trees of the field shall yield their fruit, and the earth shall yield its increase, and they shall be secure in their land. And they shall know that I am the LORD, when I break the bars of their yoke and deliver them from the hand of those who enslaved them.
verses.comment: Symbolizes abundance and spiritual liberation, drawing on Exodus motifs of deliverance.

verses.text: They shall no more be prey to the nations, nor shall the beasts of the land devour them. They shall dwell securely, and none shall make them afraid.
verses.comment: God’s presence grants lasting security.

verses.text: And I will raise up for them a planting of renown, so that they shall never again be consumed with hunger in the land, and suffer the scorn of the nations.
verses.comment: ‘Planting of renown’ points to a righteous shoot or messianic figure (see Isaiah 4:2), fulfilled in Jesus.

verses.text: And they shall know that I am the LORD their God with them, and that they, the house of Israel, are my people, says the Lord GOD.
verses.comment: Divine indwelling is fulfilled in the Incarnation: 'God with us.'

verses.text: And you are my sheep, the sheep of my pasture, and I am your God, declares the Lord GOD.
verses.comment: Concludes with the intimate covenant relationship between God and His people, establishing identity in the ongoing, visible community God shepherds.
